filme.sinopse: A stripper and single mother gets dragged into a dangerous situation after a congressman takes a fancy to her.
filme.storyline: Erin Grant loses care and custody of her daughter when she's divorced from her husband Darrell, a small-time thief. Struggling for money, she is a dancer at a nightclub, where one night Congressman Dilbeck (in disguise) attacks another member of the audience. A spectator, who recognizes Dilbeck and is fond of Erin, offers to get back her daughter by blackmailing Dilbeck. Things do not work out as planned, though.

These strippers are different because they're naive, put upon, victims being forced to degrade themselves for icky men against their will. None of them are just whores or anything, and all of them, especially our heroine, have angelic hearts of gold. They are protected by large African American guardian "Shad". Unable to win custody through legal means as a result of her occupation as a stripper, Erin illegally abducts the child. An elderly congressmen attempts to recruit Erin into his harem, using knowledge of the illegal abduction as leverage. You can pretty much use your imagination for everything that happens next. From here, the cliché abuse continues as it becomes a foregone conclusion that Erin is a near perfect mother and there is never any meaningfully developed conflict about her struggle raising a child given her choice of occupation. However, the judge's memories of Darrell's days as a football hero win him custody of their daughter, and Erin, concerned for her child's safety, is determined to fight the decision. Erin has just lost her position as a secretary for the FBI, so, to cover her legal bills, she takes a job as an exotic dancer at a strip club called the Eager Beaver. While she has no experience taking off her clothes in front of an audience, Erin soon makes friends with the fellow dancers and finds a protector in the club's burly but good-hearted bouncer, Shad. However, when the man with the photo turns up dead, Erin discovers that Dillbeck's people play a bit rougher than she expected. While Andrew Bergman's adaptation fails to capture the essence of Carl Hiaasen's satirical novel it nevertheless is nowhere near as bad as its reputation suggests. Demi Moore, whose career was already on a downward slide judging by the number of times she bares her breasts, plays a mother who is forced to work in a strip joint to earn the income necessary to fight for custody of her daughter, the care of whom a condescending judge has awarded to her low-life husband (Robert Patrick). While on the job, she catches the eye of a sleazy senator (Burt Reynolds) who is prepared to go to any odds to have her perform a private dance. While it's fair to say that the film completely botches the satirical aspects of Hiaasen's story, it still manages to provide an absorbing story after an undeniably shaky start. The nudity isn't as in your face as you'd expect, and in fact becomes almost incidental as the story moves along. The cast are all reasonably good, with Reynolds and Patrick in particular standing out: Reynold's character could have been something of a classic had it been toned down a little  although he's still likable in a sleazy sort of way, he's just too downright weird for the audience to take to him completely. Patrick's low-life husband is also likable despite his failings and Patrick works hard to make him this way. His drunken intrusion into the senator's long-awaited private dance with a cheery 'evenin' party-goers' is one of the funniest things I've seen in a while. Ving Rhames also scores as an outwardly surly bouncer with a soft spot for all the girls in his charge. I suppose in a way, Striptease has something of an advantage due to its reputation: you come into it expecting very little, so the fact that it's got an engrossing  if far-fetched plot  works in its favour. Worth a try if you're in the mood.

The mix really doesn't work, and the clash between Demi Moore's overly serious acting and Burt Reynolds' whatever the hell Burt Reynolds was doing couldn't be more off-putting. My vote: 3/10 for Ving and Rena alone.

Striptease is about a stripper who becomes involved in both a child- custody dispute and corrupt politics.It is a sex comedy film directed, produced, and written by Andrew Bergman. The film stars Demi Moore, Burt Reynolds, and Ving Rhames. The film is based on the novel of the same name by Carl Hiaasen. The screenplay,based on a satirical novel, tells the story of Erin, who has just gotten a divorce from Darrell, the sleazy ex-con she foolishly married. However, the judge's memories of Darrell's days as a football hero win him custody of their daughter, and Erin, concerned for her child's safety, is determined to fight the decision. Erin has just lost her position as a secretary for the FBI, so, to cover her legal bills, she takes a job as an exotic dancer at a strip club called the Eager Beaver. While she has no experience taking off her clothes in front of an audience, Erin soon makes friends with the fellow dancers and finds a protector in the club's burly but good-hearted bouncer, Shad. She also makes a few fans among the regulars at the club, most notably David Dillbeck, a drunken lout with a bottomless appetite for sleaze -- who also happens to be a conservative congressman with ties to right-wing religious groups. One of Erin's admirers snaps a photo of her with the congressman when a brawl breaks out at the club, and he suggests that it would make fine blackmail material. However, when the man with the photo turns up dead, Erin discovers that Dillbeck's people play a bit rougher than she expected. Jane,practically placed Moore's stardom into a downhill and it never recovered since then.She could have been a better actress had she chosen better materials after attaining popularity in Ghost instead of going for the high paycheck that movie offers come her way that does nothing except use her star appeal rather than her showcase her acting ability.

While Andrew Bergman's adaptation fails to capture the essence of Carl Hiaasen's satirical novel it nevertheless is nowhere near as bad as its reputation suggests. Demi Moore, whose career was already on a downward slide judging by the number of times she bares her breasts, plays a mother who is forced to work in a strip joint to earn the income necessary to fight for custody of her daughter, the care of whom a condescending judge has awarded to her low-life husband (Robert Patrick). While on the job, she catches the eye of a sleazy senator (Burt Reynolds) who is prepared to go to any odds to have her perform a private dance. While it's fair to say that the film completely botches the satirical aspects of Hiaasen's story, it still manages to provide an absorbing story after an undeniably shaky start. The nudity isn't as in your face as you'd expect, and in fact becomes almost incidental as the story moves along. The cast are all reasonably good, with Reynolds and Patrick in particular standing out: Reynold's character could have been something of a classic had it been toned down a little  although he's still likable in a sleazy sort of way, he's just too downright weird for the audience to take to him completely. Patrick's low-life husband is also likable despite his failings and Patrick works hard to make him this way. His drunken intrusion into the senator's long-awaited private dance with a cheery 'evenin' party-goers' is one of the funniest things I've seen in a while. Ving Rhames also scores as an outwardly surly bouncer with a soft spot for all the girls in his charge. I suppose in a way, Striptease has something of an advantage due to its reputation: you come into it expecting very little, so the fact that it's got an engrossing  if far-fetched plot  works in its favour. Worth a try if you're in the mood.

review.titulo: The good, the bad and the truly atrocious
review.conteudo: The Good: VING RHAMES - I suspect the only actor who actually bothered to read the book. He had just the right mixture of menace and ineptitude; so much so that I forgot that when I read the book I'd assumed his character was white (I don't think his colour is explicitly stated); RENA RIFFEL - a truly gorgeous and sadly overlooked starlet (who was also in the oft-mentioned 'Showgirls'); underused, but looking her delicious best. The Bad: How Carl Hiaason must feel. The Truly Atrocious: Just about everything else, from hammy Bert to drammy Demi; and Pandora Peaks proving that porn-stars should not be given anything as difficult as lines. I also read somewhere that Demi Moore had "artistic"(?) control over the character of Erin written into her contract; well, this is the result - a confused and toothless adaptation of a wonderfully raunchy (and *funny*) book. Andrew Bergman doesn't show anything in his IMDb log for seven years after he penned this turkey...and it serves him right. The Lesson: Don't let the inmates take over the asylum. My vote: 3/10 for Ving and Rena alone.

review.titulo: At least Showgirls had personality, what was this?
review.conteudo: I was cruising through my movie channels and I saw that Striptease was playing, I remember seeing the trailer for this movie back in 1994 when I was a kid and wanted to see it, oh, my parents had to forbid it. But of course since I'm 23 and on my own, I think I was allowed to view it. I kinda wish now that I had my parents here to tell me no because this movie was really bad. I mean most people make fun of Showgirls, I mean yeah, it's understandable, but at least that had personality and more memorable moments than this. Demi Moore just strips down to some really depressing music and this movie has the strangest humor in the world. I could see how some people might get a kick out of it, but over all it just a bad movie, it has no zest and nothing to make it special. A story about a stripper... OK, here it goes. The film revolves around Erin Grant, a former FBI secretary, who loses custody of her young daughter Angela to her ex-husband Darrell. In order to afford an appeal, Erin becomes a stripper at the Eager Beaver, a Miami strip club. A Congressman named David Dilbeck visits the club and immediately begins to adore Grant. Aware of Dilbeck's embarrassing indulgences, another Eager Beaver patron approaches Erin with a plan to manipulate the Congressman to settle the custody dispute in Erin's favor. However, Dilbeck has powerful business connections who want to ensure he remains in office. Consequently, those who can embarrass him in an election are murdered. Meanwhile, Erin retrieves her daughter from her negligent husband. Dilbeck's personal interest in Erin persists, and she is invited to perform privately for him. He asks her to become his lover and later his wife, despite his staff's concerns that she knows too much information. A debate occurs as to whether to kill Erin or simply keep her quiet by threatening to take away her daughter. Demi is alright in the movie, if even that, I'm being pretty generous considering she let her daughter, Rumor, act as her daughter in this movie. If I were Rumor, I'd be like "next time, I pick the mother/daughter bonding event". I wouldn't really feel like watching my mother dance around naked for men nore a camera. Well Rumor must have gotten a huge raise in her allowance for that to happen. But anyways, I wouldn't recommend Striptease, it was a sleazy movie, I would even go as far to say that if you want sleaze, go for Showgirls, it's more fun to watch and make fun of, this was just a sad movie. 1/10
